author: By Maggie Astor
title: Peter Navarro, Trump Trade Adviser, Heads From Prison to Convention
description: The former Trump administration official completed a four-month sentence for contempt of Congress and will speak at the Republican National Convention on Wednesday.
content: Peter Navarro, who led the U.S. Office of Trade and Manufacturing Policy under President Donald J. Trump, was released from prison on Wednesday — in time to fly to Milwaukee to speak at the Republican National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: Daniel Craig, Is That You Under Those Bangs?
description: A recent ad campaign for Loewe features the former James Bond as he has never been seen.
content: When Loewe’s new men’s campaign featuring a shaggy-chic Daniel Craig dropped recently, it stirred reactions from fashionistas and Bond buffs alike. One general sentiment was: What happened to 007?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Jessica Gunning of ‘Baby Reindeer’ Never Saw Martha as a ‘Baddie’
description: The actress, who plays a stalker in the hit Netflix series, said she has always believed her character is in many ways “quite charming and innocent.”
content: Jessica Gunning is still a little stunned by the size of the audience “Baby Reindeer” has found, and the acclaim that has followed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bianca Pallaro, Amy Julia Harris and Jack Healy
title: Guns Are Woven Into the Life of Shooter’s Hometown
description: The gunman who opened fire at a Trump rally grew up in an area where hunting and target shooting have long been popular pastimes. Now, there’s new talk of gun regulation.
content: Thomas Crooks did not have to look far beyond his hometown in western Pennsylvania to find opportunities to arm himself, buy ammunition and practice shooting before he headed to a political rally last weekend and tried to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 17, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 17, 2024.
content: An article on Saturday about the ways in which former President Trump has blurred the lines between politics and business misstated the location of 45footwear L.L.C., the company selling Mr. Trump’s $399 golden sneakers. It is in a lawyer’s office in Wyoming, not Montana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $400,000 Homes in Oklahoma, Alabama and Nebraska
description: A Tudor Revival home in Oklahoma City, a two-bedroom condominium in a converted 1869 warehouse in Mobile and a 1915 American Foursquare house in Omaha.
content: This house is in the Gatewood neighborhood, a few blocks from Gatewood Elementary School and Oklahoma City University, a private school with about 1,400 undergraduate students. It is less than a mile from Oklahoma Children’s Theatre and a five-minute drive from McKinley Park, which has a splash pad and a playground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Britain Needs to Move Faster on Climate, Monitoring Group Says
description: A report by a government body that oversees efforts to reduce greenhouse gases will help underpin the Labour Party’s plans to accelerate renewable energy and other measures.
content: An influential government body gave what amounts to strong support Thursday to one of the main planks of the new British government’s plans to revitalize the economy: a crash program to accelerate efforts for dealing with climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Mother Whose Son Died of Fentanyl Poisoning Brings Some Delegates to Tears
description: Anne Fundner blamed the death of her 15-year-old son, who took fentanyl-laced pills, on President Biden’s border policies.
content: Anne Fundner, a California woman whose 15-year-old son died in 2022 after taking pills laced with fentanyl, faulted President Biden on Tuesday night over his border policies and the flow of illegal opioids into the United States during an emotional speech at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Focusing In on One Star, Fancams Find a Love of the Movies
description: The creators of clips about Swann Arlaud (“Anatomy of a Fall”) and others have found a way to make cinephilia a communal experience in the digital age.
content: When I first saw “Anatomy of a Fall” back at the Cannes Film Festival in 2023, I expected that the courtroom drama would be critically acclaimed. I could even imagine an Oscar win. What I did not foresee was the fancams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Promise of a Changed U.K. Comes Wrapped in Royal Tradition
description: From plans to tackle climate change to ending the role of hereditary legislators, the ceremonial King’s Speech showcased the progressive priorities of Britain’s Labour government.
content: At last, a “King’s Speech” that the king himself might have written, at least in its bridge-building, planet-saving passages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jon Stewart Razzes a ‘Daily Show’ Guest: Bill O’Reilly
description: The former Fox host, a longtime foil of the show, said he knew he had “no friends here.” “Well, not just here,” Stewart replied.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Ranking Every Taylor Swift Album, Worst to Best
description: Two longtime chroniclers of Swift’s career list their favorites — and least favorites — of the singer’s 11 original studio albums so far.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes a conversation about Taylor Swift’s full catalog of albums so far, ranked worst to best.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘My Spy the Eternal City’ Review: An Explosive Roman Holiday
description: The sequel stars a teenage Sophie (Chloe Coleman), who goes on a school trip to Italy with J.J. (Dave Bautista) as her burly chaperone.
content: Watching the new teen comedy “My Spy the Eternal City,” the attentive viewer may begin to wonder about the role of Anna Faris. The endlessly inventive performer spends the first half of the movie smothering the light of her comedic virtuosity under a bushel of a part as a humorless high school principal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: How Yale Propelled J.D. Vance’s Career
description: The G.O.P. vice-presidential nominee is remembered as a warm and personable student. But some are perplexed by what they see as his shift in ideology.
content: When J.D. Vance applied to law school, he viewed it as a pathway out of his chaotic upbringing in working-class Middletown, Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Is Maddow in Milwaukee? No, That’s an LED Screen on MSNBC.
description: A production technique gave the impression that Rachel Maddow and other star anchors were reporting in Milwaukee, not from 30 Rockefeller Plaza.
content: MSNBC’s prime-time coverage of the Republican National Convention has featured a typical TV tableau: anchors at a desk perched high above the convention floor, pontificating as the starred-and-striped political pomp unfolds below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Now a Felon, Menendez Sees His Political Future Fast Evaporating
description: Senator Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat, was found guilty of bribery and corruption. Leaders in his party are pressuring him to resign.
content: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey barreled toward a confrontation with his own party on Wednesday, as fellow senators demanded he resign from office after his conviction in a sweeping bribery scheme, or face the possibility of a rare expulsion vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Babydog, a Plump Bulldog Who Is Apparently a Republican, Charms the R.N.C.
description: Gov. Jim Justice of West Virginia, running for Senate in his deep-red state, was somewhat upstaged as the crowd shouted “Babydog!” with an energy generally reserved only for former President Donald J. Trump.
content: The crowd gathered on the second night of the Republican National Convention was promised a 60-pound bulldog. And when Gov. Jim Justice of West Virginia walked on to the stage without one on Tuesday night, they began shouting the dog’s name in annoyance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By W. M. Akers
title: The Lost Art of Mummy Smuggling
description: In “Women in the Valley of the Kings,” Kathleen Sheppard introduces us to a group of 19th-century archaeologists who changed the field forever.
content: Let’s say it’s 1873. You’re an intrepid Englishwoman sailing the Nile in search of adventure and history and souvenirs. You’ve sneaked a painted sarcophagus onto your boat. You open the lid, unwrap the occupant and admire what you declare to be a “festive object and not at all a funereal old frump.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: J.D. Vance Once Warned Trump About Lying About Elections. That Was Then.
description: Once he ran for office, Mr. Vance, Donald J. Trump’s new running mate, embraced Mr. Trump’s false theories about voter fraud and elections.
content: In the last days of the 2016 presidential campaign, when Donald J. Trump preemptively accused Hillary Clinton of stealing an election that many assumed Mr. Trump would lose, his critics included his future running mate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Hiker’s Death Prompts Move to Allow Wider Bear Cull in Romania
description: But some experts described the planned cull as excessive and said it would not keep people safe.
content: When a wild bear attack led to the death of a 19-year-old hiker in Romania last week, the episode terrified people across the country and inspired a storm of horrified tabloid headlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘UnPrisoned’ Review: Kerry Washington Handles Comedy, Too
description: The star of “Scandal” demonstrates her range in the Hulu series about an ex-con’s daughter and her relatable traumas.
content: Paige Alexander, the high-maintenance mom played by Kerry Washington in the Hulu dramedy “UnPrisoned,” puts her family and friends through a lot. She’s also a challenge for the show’s captioners: Rendering her continual nervous laughter, which punctuates the soundtrack like the sputtering of a rusty muffler, calls for creativity. In Season 1, (laughs), (laughter) and (laughing) were supplemented with (snickers), (snorts), (chuckles), (chuckles awkwardly) and other descriptors of uncomfortable mirth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: A Wildly Obscene Term’s Path to Mainstream Usage
description: When combined with innocuous acts, “rawdogging” has left its overtly sexual origins behind, just like many other dirty slang words of the past.
content: If you suddenly feel like you’re noticing the term “rawdogging” used widely and in surprising contexts — online, in the office, at the bar — you’re not alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: ‘Banger of a Recipe, Easy and Better Than the Sum of Its Parts!’
description: Hetty Lui McKinnon’s corn salad with mango and halloumi has raves for a reason.
content: Tomato salads may be the go-to apotheosis of summer produce, but corn salads are just as much a rite of the season. Vibrantly yellow, juicy-crisp and pleasingly sweet without being cloying, they are open to whatever ingredients you care to add, depending on what’s in your heart — and your fridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: World’s Rarest Whale Washes Up on New Zealand Beach, Scientists Say
description: Only six specimens of the spade-toothed whale have ever been identified. This carcass could be the first that scientists are able to dissect.
content: Residents of New Zealand, a hot spot for whale and dolphin strandings, are used to finding large sea creatures beached on their shores. But the creature that washed up on a beach in the nation’s south earlier this month — about 16 feet long, distinctively colored, its teeth snapped off — was no ordinary whale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Tracey Tully
title: Menendez Tells Allies He Is Considering Resigning After Conviction
description: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey was found guilty on Tuesday in a sweeping corruption scheme and faces a potential expulsion vote.
content: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey has privately told allies that he is considering resigning from Congress after his conviction in a sweeping bribery scheme rather than face a potential expulsion vote, according to three people familiar with his remarks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Jack Healy and Luke Broadwater
title: Gunman’s Phone Had Details About Both Trump and Biden, F.B.I. Officials Say
description: The disclosure, during private briefings to lawmakers in the House and Senate, offered more details from the early stages of the investigation into the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump.
content: F.B.I. officials told members of Congress on Wednesday that the gunman who tried to kill former President Donald J. Trump used his cellphone and other devices to search for images of Mr. Trump and President Biden, along with an array of public figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Vaccines Significantly Reduce the Risk of Long Covid, Study Finds
description: In the first two years of the pandemic, the rate of long Covid was starkly lower among people who were vaccinated, researchers reported.
content: A large new study provides some of the strongest evidence yet that vaccines reduce the risk of developing long Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small and Julia Jacobs
title: T. Rex Dethroned? A Stegosaurus Fossil Sells for a Record $44.6 Million.
description: The stegosaurus had been expected to sell for between $4 million and $6 million. It set a record in the contentious fossil trade, where scientists fear being priced out of the market.
content: Sotheby’s sold an unusually complete stegosaurus fossil at auction on Wednesday for a staggering $44.6 million, toppling the record fossil price that had previously been set by the king of the dinosaur world, the Tyrannosaurus rex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Moving in Childhood Contributes to Depression, Study Finds
description: A study of more than a million Danes found that frequent moves in childhood had a bigger effect than poverty on adult mental health risk.
content: In recent decades, mental health providers began screening for “adverse childhood experiences” — generally defined as abuse, neglect, violence, family dissolution and poverty — as risk factors for later disorders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: For These Nearly Extinct Crocodiles, Life Found a Way
description: The largest population of the endangered Siamese crocodiles this century hatched in Cambodia, a big moment for the conservation of a wild species once on the brink of extinction.
content: Tiny snouts and long tails. Checkerboards of black and brown scales. Eggs the size of oranges cracking alongside hatchlings mewling and chirping like a choir of baby birds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: At Moms for Liberty Event, Ron DeSantis Was a Throwback to an Earlier Time
description: An event in Milwaukee on Tuesday hosted by the conservative group Moms for Liberty and featuring Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida recalled what might have been in the 2024 presidential race.
content: When Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida took the stage on Tuesday afternoon for the first time during the Republican National Convention, at an ornate old theater down the street from the arena where the convention was unfolding, it was possible to glimpse a moment he had imagined a year ago when he started what became his failed presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch and Judson Jones
title: Flash Flooding in Arkansas Leads to Rescues and Evacuations
description: Rainfall of 6 to 11 inches overnight prompted a rare flash flood emergency in Marion County, where water rose inside homes and overtook bridges.
content: Water rescues and evacuations took place in northern Arkansas on Wednesday morning, as rising water inundated homes and businesses and prompted the National Weather Service to issue a rare flash flood emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
title: In a Bangkok Hotel Room, Six Bodies and Traces of Cyanide
description: A case that shocked Thailand, the police indicated on Wednesday, was one of murder-suicide.
content: The luxury hotel room, a suite, had been locked for nearly a day. The bowls of tom yum soup and plates of stir-fried vegetables and fried rice had been left untouched. But there was something far more ominous in the room: six bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Biden vs. His Party
description: The Democratic Party’s Biden dilemma is unresolved, even as the momentum against him slows.
content: What happens when a politician’s interest diverges from his party’s interests? That’s the question facing the Democratic Party, and it is the subject of today’s newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: J.D. Vance Plants His Appalachian Roots in the 2024 Race
description: The newly anointed Republican vice-presidential candidate leaned into his impoverished upbringing at the party’s convention, and frequently name-dropped the battleground states around his native Ohio.
content: Senator J.D. Vance drew a direct line on Wednesday from his traumatic upbringing in southwest Ohio to his new standing as the top lieutenant in Donald J. Trump’s conservative movement, promising the Republican National Convention that he would bring his working-class roots to Washington and help fight “for the people who built this country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: President Biden’s growing isolation.
content: As President Biden contends with the rebellion against his candidacy within his own party, he has relied for advice on family members and a few loyalists, who are true believers in the mythology of Joe Biden as the “comeback kid.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Jeanna Smialek
title: Local Officer Fired at Trump Gunman as Gunshots Rang Out, Official Says
description: The officer did not fire the kill shot, but did “engage” the gunman, the Butler County district attorney said.
content: One of the local police officers deployed at the Trump rally in Butler, Pa., on Saturday shot at the would-be assassin as he was firing toward the former president, Richard Goldinger, the district attorney of Butler County, said in an interview on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Wall St. Journal Reporter Says She Was Fired Over Hong Kong Union Role
description: The journalist accused her former employer of failing to stand up for press freedom, a claim that the newspaper rejected.
content: A Wall Street Journal reporter in Hong Kong said on Wednesday that she had been fired over her role as the leader of a journalists’ trade union that has come under attack by the territory’s pro-Beijing leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: ‘Memory Saved Us’: How France Blocked the Far Right
description: The French had a far-right government before, one that collaborated with the Nazis. When casting ballots even today, that is not an easy thing to forget.
content: Until the last ballot box came in from a nearby suburb, Fabrice Barusseau bit his nails: Would he or his far-right opponent be sitting in the French Parliament in Paris?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: In Milwaukee, a G.O.P. Transformation From Dysfunctional to Unified
description: On Tuesday, Republicans effectively took a victory lap in the middle of the presidential race, expressing a sense of invincibility at their convention.
content: For eight chaotic years, Republicans battled in public and private, fighting over Donald J. Trump’s polarizing personality, his divisive policies and his history of electoral defeats through lawsuits and leadership battles, felony convictions and suburban defections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: A Milan Airport Is Now Named for Berlusconi. Cue the ‘Bunga-Bunga’ Memes.
description: The decision to name Italy’s second-largest passenger hub after the divisive media mogul and politician, who died in 2023, has prompted outrage and protests.
content: Millions of travelers pass through Italian airports every year, but most probably don’t know that Rome’s airport is named for Leonardo da Vinci, Pisa’s is named for Galileo Galilei, and Palermo’s is named for Giovanni Falcone and Paolo Borsellino, two prosecutors who were murdered in 1992 as payback for their anti-Mafia crusades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Beckman
title: Anchovies Are Always a Good Idea
description: This diminutive fish has been making other things taste great for millenniums.
content: To understand anchovies, you need to understand umami.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Friba Rezayee
title: The Olympics Should Stand With Afghanistan’s Women Athletes
description: None of the women on the Olympic team live in Afghanistan, nor could they visit without risking their lives. They deserve places on the refugee team.
content: When the Taliban regained control of Afghanistan in 2021, one of its first actions was to bar women and girls from participating in sports publicly. It came as no surprise to me, one of Afghanistan’s first two female Olympians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Weiner
title: We Owe Shannen Doherty an Apology
description: Gen X’s quintessential bad girl was never really all that bad.
content: Shannen Doherty was difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: J.D. Vance’s A.I. Agenda: Reduce Regulation
description: Donald Trump’s vice-presidential pick has indicated he favors a hands-off approach to A.I. but also wants to increase scrutiny of the biggest tech firms in the field.
content: Senator J.D. Vance, Republican of Ohio, is a strong skeptic of regulating artificial intelligence. He’s also in favor of reining in Big Tech, companies he says have grown so powerful that they stymie smaller companies’ ability to succeed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: Elizabeth Debicki on Her Second Emmy Nomination for Princess Diana
description: The actor’s supporting actress nod was one of 18 nominations the show received for its final season. She called the honor “a really beautiful end” to her time on the show.
content: Elizabeth Debicki earned an Emmy nomination for outstanding supporting actress in a drama series on Wednesday, her second nomination for playing Princess Diana on “The Crown.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: ‘No Fear, No Die’: Claire Denis’s Noir Comes Home to Roost
description: The French filmmaker’s confident third feature has been largely overlooked. Thankfully, a newly restored version is getting its first New York run since 1992.
content: Most celebrated for “Beau Travail,” her sensuous transposition of Herman Melville’s “Billy Budd” to an African outpost of France’s Foreign Legion, Claire Denis could be the strongest French filmmaker of the post-New Wave generation. She is certainly the greatest risk-taker — unafraid to eroticize her male actors, unleash outré violence, or subsume an elusive narrative in a fiercely lyrical force field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Says He’d Consider Dropping Out if a ‘Medical Condition’ Emerged
description: President Biden has said none of his doctors have told him he has a serious medical condition. But his debate performance last month raised questions about his health and acuity.
content: Follow the latest news on Biden’s re-election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: What Responsibility Do I Have to Ensure the Safety of an Illicit Cat?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the duty one has to neighbors — and a forbidden pet in harm’s way.
content: My husband and I live in a multiunit building that does not allow pets. Despite this, one of our immediate neighbors has a cat. It isn’t noisy or bothersome, so we see no reason to snitch on them. The concern is that recently we have had a mice problem in our unit. We have tried many mechanical pet-safe solutions, for our health and the health of the neighbor’s cat, but to no avail. We contacted an exterminator who recommends a chemical repellent, and have gotten permission from the homeowners’ association to go forward, but our neighbor has privately expressed worries it could harm the cat. What responsibility do we have to ensure the safety of the cat? We do not want to cause any harm to someone’s pet, but we also cannot live with mice, and a more aggressive plan seems necessary. — Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Josephs
title: ‘Shogun’ Dominates Emmys With 25 Nominations
description: The historical drama has been renewed for “likely” two more seasons after being billed originally as a limited series.
content: The FX hit “Shogun,” an ensemble drama set in 17th-century Japan, has been nominated for 25 Emmys, the most of any series this year. The show is in competition for several of the night’s biggest drama categories, including outstanding drama series, lead actor (Hiroyuki Sanada), lead actress (Anna Sawai) and outstanding directing (Frederick E.O. Toye).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Donald Trump Jr. Is Building a ‘MAGA Bench.’ J.D. Vance Is Just the Start.
description: The former president’s son played a pivotal role in getting Mr. Vance on the G.O.P. ticket. Though he has never held elected office, he has emerged as a key enforcer of MAGA loyalty.
content: When J.D. Vance did his initial walk-through of the Republican National Convention stage this week after he was named Donald J. Trump’s running mate, the Ohio senator was joined not just by aides and event organizers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Easy, Summery Bean Salad Has a Cheesy Crunch
description: Melissa Clark swaps Parmesan crisps for croutons in this quick, hearty no-cook recipe.
content: As a Caesar salad enthusiast, I’ve seen my share of crouton stand-ins. Some are quite good (crumbled pretzels, fried chickpeas, toasted pumpkin seeds), while others are mere wannabes. (Wasabi peas, ahem. Dried apple chips? Don’t get me started.) But not a single one holds a candle to that queen of crunch, the frico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Nate Schweber
title: City Councilwoman Is Charged With Biting Police Chief During Protest
description: Susan Zhuang, who represents a Brooklyn district, was protesting at the site of a proposed homeless shelter. The authorities said she resisted arrest with her teeth.
content: A New York City councilwoman was charged with assault after a heated protest at the Brooklyn site of a proposed men’s homeless shelter at which, the authorities say, she bit a police chief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Curtis, Wendy Dorr, Sloane Crosley and Sonia Herrero
title: A Kidnapping and Its Consequences
description: A new novel from the author of “Fleishman Is in Trouble.”
content: “Long Island Compromise,” Taffy Brodesser-Akner’s latest novel, features a wealthy Jewish family on Long Island from 1980 until the present. Brodesser-Akner fictionalizes a true story about a kidnapping and the complex repercussions it has on the family. Sloane Crosley, an author and contributor to The New York Times Book Review, says she has “never really read a book that covers suburban Jewishness quite the way this one does.” “Long Island Compromise” is out now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: What Would Persuade Biden to Step Aside? Here’s What He’s Said.
description: The president has insisted he is committed to running, but his list of scenarios in which he might reconsider has grown.
content: Ever since President Biden’s listless performance at a debate last month, he has faced the same question: What would it take for him to consider dropping out of the race?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Annie Karni
title: Rubio’s Endorsement of Trump Underscores Reversal for Latino Leader
description: Many Hispanic Republicans watched with pride as the Florida senator spoke, but some expressed disappointment over his defense of Trump.
content: Senator Marco Rubio’s endorsement of Donald J. Trump at the Republican National Convention on Tuesday made the Florida Republican the highest elected Latino leader to fall in line behind the former president. It was also a pivotal point in Mr. Rubio’s nearly 14-year journey from being a rising star of his party to a keynote speaker during the coronation of a onetime rival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Rust’ Armorer Asks for New Trial After Dismissal of Alec Baldwin’s Case
description: Lawyers for the armorer, Hannah Gutierrez-Reed, are seizing on a judge’s dramatic dismissal of the actor’s case to argue for her release from prison.
content: The armorer who was convicted of involuntary manslaughter for loading a live round into a gun on the “Rust” movie set, resulting in the fatal shooting of its cinematographer, asked a court in New Mexico on Tuesday for a new trial following the collapse of the case against Alec Baldwin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle and Derek Arthur
title: Donald Trump’s Choice for V.P. ‘Is Not a Unity Pick’
description: Michelle Cottle on what to know ahead of J.D. Vance’s R.N.C. speech on Wednesday night.
content: J.D. Vance has gone from a working-class memoirist to the Republican vice-presidential nominee. Here, the Opinion writer Michelle Cottle introduces listeners to the man whom Donald Trump has picked to be his running mate. Plus, hear what Republican National Convention attendees think of the winner of the Republican veepstakes so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: The Plain Croissant Is Still the Best Croissant
description: In an era of extreme lamination and viral hybrid pastries, the original model remains an absolute marvel.
content: I left the bustle of Petitgrain Boulangerie in Santa Monica, Calif., with a plain croissant still hot from the oven, and though I tried to let it cool, I couldn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: There’s No Zealot Like a Trump Convert
description: The Republican Party is full of people who have changed their minds about the former president.
content: Good evening from Milwaukee, where I had a relish tray last night. Today, I’m looking at how the Republican National Convention has become a conversion story. Then, we zoom into a light-blue state where Republicans think they have a shot in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Opposition to Abortion Rights Is at Center of J.D. Vance’s Political Career
description: As he joins Donald J. Trump’s presidential ticket, Mr. Vance is seeking to play down, and in some cases rewrite, his views.
content: Throughout his brief political career, Senator J.D. Vance of Ohio has been an unapologetic opponent of abortion rights, a view driven by his Catholic faith and one he has cited as a driving force in his agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli and Kevin Draper
title: N.B.A. Board Backs TV Rights Deals, but Steps Remain
description: The agreements, set to begin after next season, could potentially pay the league about $76 billion over 11 years.
content: The National Basketball Association’s Board of Governors has approved a set of agreements for the rights to show the league’s games, Commissioner Adam Silver said on Tuesday, moving one step closer to completing deals that would reshape how the sport is watched over the next decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: J.D. Vance Is the First Millennial on a Major Party Ticket
description: If elected, the first-term senator would become the third-youngest vice president in history.
content: Senator J.D. Vance, the 39-year-old Republican vice-presidential nominee from Ohio, is the first millennial to join a major party ticket and would become the third-youngest vice president in history if elected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadie Stein
title: The Doctor Is Out: What Do I Read Now?
description: These stories of relationship dramas and evolving partnerships will fill the “Couples Therapy”-sized hole in your life with wisdom, schadenfreude and humor — and sometimes all of the above.
content: It can be hard when shrinks go on summer vacation — especially in a summer when each news cycle seems to bring more upsetting developments to process. And it doesn’t help that the fourth season of the cult favorite Showtime docuseries “Couples Therapy” has just wrapped, so even affordable, vicarious therapy is off the table. Without our weekly fix of Dr. Orna Guralnik’s deep nods and cathartic sympathy crying — and with the good doctor’s own much-anticipated book still months off — what are we to do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: When Is a Stand-Up Special Like ‘The Wire’? When Ali Siddiq Is Onstage
description: The comedian’s YouTube epic, “The Domino Effect,” is nervy humor, with both punches and punchlines that reflect his years in prison.
content: In “The Domino Effect,” a genre-defying autobiographical epic on YouTube, the comic Ali Siddiq begins one part by casually asking the audience a question: “Has anyone here been duct-taped and thrown in a trunk?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Spent $450 Million on a Moon Rover. Now It’s Canceling the Mission.
description: Delays and concerns about NASA’s future budgets doomed the VIPER mission, which aimed to search for ice near the moon’s south pole.
content: NASA will spend about $800 million to not send a robotic rover to the moon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Megadonors Are Plotting to Change Biden’s Mind With Money. Will It Work?
description: They’re calling politicians. They’re dangling money to members of Congress. But major Democratic donors who want President Biden to step aside are also learning the limits of their powers.
content: For ultrarich Democrats, this is the golden age of political scheming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: The Most Important Seasoning After Salt and Pepper
description: Lemon lifts this pasta dish filled with gorgeously rich, smoky tomatoes.
content: So often the answer is … lemon. The questions, though, vary greatly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Allison McCann
title: A Guide to the King’s Speech: Crown Jewels, Black Rod and a Mace
description: When King Charles unveils the U.K. government’s agenda in Parliament, he is surrounded by rituals that nod to hundreds of years of history.
content: A “hostage,” a search for explosives, heaps of royal jewels and a five-foot mace. Welcome to the reopening of Britain’s Parliament, replete with ancient traditions and elaborate rituals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Tests Positive for Covid
description: President Biden will “self-isolate and will continue to carry out all of his duties fully during that time,” a White House spokeswoman said.
content: Follow the latest news on Biden’s re-election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Thursday Briefing: J.D. Vance Takes the Stage
description: Plus, Israel estimates the toll on Hamas.
content: All eyes are on Donald Trump’s running mate, J.D. Vance, who is set to deliver a prime time speech at the Republican convention in a few hours. The political newcomer, who joined the Senate just last year, has had few opportunities to connect with American voters beyond his constituents in Ohio. This will be his biggest chance to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Theodore Schleifer
title: How a Network of Tech Billionaires Helped J.D. Vance Leap Into Power
description: Mr. Vance spent less than five years in Silicon Valley’s tech industry, but the connections he made with Peter Thiel and others became crucial to his political ascent.
content: Last month, J.D. Vance flew to San Francisco to hold a fund-raiser for Donald J. Trump and to host a private dinner afterward with two dozen tech and crypto executives and investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack and Nate Schweber
title: Is That a Meteor Over Manhattan? New Yorkers Glance Up, Then Shrug.
description: It had already been a weird few weeks in New York. Then a fireball streaked across the sky.
content: New Yorkers have lived through their fair share of unusual events recently. There was an earthquake, an eclipse and the criminal trial of a former United States president, all against the backdrop of nail-biting national political crises and the hottest year on record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: What It Would Take to Deport Millions of Immigrants
description: Donald Trump is calling for the biggest deportation program in American history. The costs and hurdles would be enormous.
content: When Donald Trump ran for president in 2016, he vowed to build a wall to seal the border and keep criminals from entering the country. This campaign season, his immigration agenda has a new focus: a mass deportation program unlike anything the country has seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Takeaways From Day 2 of the R.N.C.: The Republican Unity Show
description: A roster of Donald J. Trump’s former rivals, including Nikki Haley, lined up to pledge their allegiance, and a party confident of its November fate drove home an aggressive law-and-order message.
content: The second night of the Republican National Convention was all about unity, in the party and in the nation. But in Donald J. Trump’s Republican Party, unity is not something to strive for. It is something inherent in the Make America Great Again movement — if only the elites in the news media and the Democratic Party would recognize it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Dave Loggins, Who Wrote Hits for Himself and Others, Dies at 76
description: After tasting fame with “Please Come to Boston” in 1974, he became a major Nashville songwriter. He also wrote the theme to the Masters golf tournament.
content: Dave Loggins, a chart-topping Nashville songwriter for the likes of Kenny Rogers and the Oak Ridge Boys who also notched his own Top 10 pop hit with the wistful “Please Come to Boston” and wrote the enduring theme for the Masters golf tournament, died on July 10 in Nashville. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Winston, Celebrity Gorilla at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park, Dies at 52
description: The great ape was euthanized because his health had declined, staff members said.
content: Winston, a silverback who ruled over a peaceful gorilla kingdom at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park for decades and whose 451-pound frame concealed his tender personality, died on Saturday. He was 52.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Schiff Calls on Biden to Drop Out of Presidential Race
description: Representative Adam Schiff of California, a top House Democrat running for Senate, told The Los Angeles Times that he had serious concerns about whether President Biden could win.
content: Follow the latest news on Biden’s re-election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Renauld White, Debonair Model Who Broke Barriers, Dies at 80
description: The first Black American model to appear on the cover of GQ magazine, he was an avatar of male beauty for nearly half a century.
content: Renauld White, who is widely considered to be the country’s first Black male supermodel — and who for nearly half a century was an elegant and enduring image of American style, walking the runways for Bill Blass, Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein, Jeffrey Banks and Donna Karan, as well as being the first Black American model to appear on the cover of GQ magazine — died on June 26 in Manhattan. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Republicans’ Depressingly Effective Minority Outreach Strategy
description: If Democrats don’t stop laughing at this G.O.P. effort they may soon need an “autopsy” of their own.
content: The 2020 Republican National Convention featured a procession of minority speakers that was, as reported at the time, almost certainly unprecedented.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: J.D. Vance Has Written of His Struggles to Control His Anger
description: In his book “Hillbilly Elegy,” Mr. Vance chronicles the conflict and violence that shaped him and says his wife has helped him manage his emotions.
content: Senator J.D. Vance’s rapid political evolution from a moderate Republican to a leader of former President Donald J. Trump’s movement is one of the best-known aspects of his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Igielnik
title: New Polling Shows a Large and Growing Majority Want Biden to Step Aside
description: The new survey also shows Americans, including a significant number of Democrats, lack confidence in the president’s ability to do the job and that a sizable share of Democrats think he can’t win.
content: Nearly two-thirds of Democrats said President Biden should step aside and allow the party to select a different nominee, according to a new poll from the AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Jon Hamm Talks Emmy Nods for ‘Fargo’ and ‘The Morning Show’
description: His roles both had close real-world analogues, the first a power-hungry Christian nationalist, the second an Elon Musk-like character.
content: Jon Hamm is back in the Emmy Awards saddle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The California Ties at the Top of the Presidential Ticket
description: Vice President Kamala Harris’s credentials are already well-known. But Senator J.D. Vance of Ohio has deep connections to the Golden State, too.
content: The 2024 presidential race just got even more Californian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,125, Thursday, July 18, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Slagle
title: Who Needs a Recipe to Cook a Hot Dog, Anyway?
description: Sometimes, the easiest dishes are the toughest to get just right. Ali Slagle, who develops recipes for Times Cooking, wants to help home chefs make fan-favorite foods ‘with feeling.’
content: You might not need a recipe to grill a hot dog, make a slice of cinnamon toast or whip up a bacon, egg and cheese sandwich. A recipe might just get in the way. It’s simple food — why complicate it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: ‘The Bear’ Breaks an Emmy Comedy Record. But Is It Actually a Comedy?
description: The show set a new high for the most Emmy nominations in a single year for a comedy series, beating out “30 Rock” for the record.
content: “Yes, Chef” is now part of Emmy history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Bullet’s Graze Seen as Sign of ‘God’s Protection’
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 17, 2024.
content: “I mean, he turned his head right when the bullet went past him.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: HBO Falls to Third at the Emmys for the First Time Since 1996
description: HBO earned 91 Emmy nominations, trailing both Netflix, which took 107, and FX, which had 93.
content: The last time HBO ranked in third place among television outlets in total Emmy nominations, Bill Clinton and Bob Dole were gearing up for a presidential election and the “Macarena” was sweeping the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Ford and Mellon Foundations Name 2024 Disability Futures Fellows
description: The 20 recipients, including a Broadway composer, a Marvel video game voice actress and a three-time Pushcart Prize-nominated poet, are the initiative’s final cohort.
content: The Ford and Andrew W. Mellon Foundations on Wednesday named the 2024 Disability Futures Fellows — the latest class of disabled writers, filmmakers, musicians and other creative artists who will receive unrestricted $50,000 awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Amazon Workers Narrowly Reject Union Drive at British Warehouse
description: The vote, which would have forced the tech giant to negotiate collectively with workers, was the closest an Amazon center in Britain had come to being unionized.
content: A fight to form the first union at an Amazon warehouse in Britain came to an end this week, as organizers of the effort fell short by just 28 votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Shawn Hubler, Rick Rojas, Kurt Streeter and Amy Qin
title: ‘Our Nation Is Not Well’: Voters Fear What Could Happen Next
description: There is growing anxiety that the country’s political divide is nearly beyond repair, and the assassination attempt on Donald Trump only made things worse.
content: Before Saturday, when Butler, Pa., became the latest stunned backdrop for the nation’s  political fury, Mayor Bob Dandoy thought of his town as a place that had learned to work around party lines. A Democrat in a Republican stronghold, he had campaigned on consensus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Aftersun,’ ‘Anomalisa’ and More Streaming Gems
description: An Oscar-nominated father-daughter drama and a stop-motion dramedy are among the best movies hiding in the corners of your subscription streaming services.
content: Charlotte Wells writes and directs this stunning memory play, which begins as a wandering account of a divorced father (Paul Mescal) and his 11-year-old daughter (Frankie Corio), on holiday for his birthday; the mood is languid and mellow, capturing the carefree dreaminess of vacation, with nowhere to be and nothing to do. But this is no mere hangout, and Wells expertly deploys brief but affecting flash-forwards to snap the story she’s telling into focus, juxtaposing glowing, nostalgic memories with the cold, tough present. It’s a tour-de-force of instinctive, emotional filmmaking, anchored by the dazzling acting of Mescal (deservedly Oscar-nominated) and Corio (who turns in one of the best performances by a young actor in recent memory).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: ‘Conscious Gardening’: Why Your Garden Needs a Mission Statement
description: Setting a clear intention can improve your design decisions and plant choices — especially if you’re “a nursery grabber” who makes impulse buys at the garden center.
content: Nicole Juday, Rob Cardillo and I were most of the way through taping an episode of my podcast when the conversation veered toward a group confessional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: In a Porridge Box, an Ancient Treasure Mysteriously Arrives in Dublin
description: The National Museum of Ireland received two copper Bronze Age ax heads in the mail. Now it needs to figure out who found them.
content: They arrived in a Flahavan’s porridge box, their gnarled edges tightly wedged into rudimentary, makeshift foam packaging, shaky pen marks still visible from where the sender had outlined their shape: two paddle-shaped copper ax heads, their hand-carved edges long since dulled by time — 4,000 years’ worth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Where to Stream 2024 Emmy-Nominated Series: ‘Shogun,’ ‘The Bear’ and More
description: Nominations for the 76th Primetime Emmy Awards were announced on Wednesday. The Emmys ceremony is planned for Sept. 15, on ABC.
content: Nominations for the 76th Primetime Emmy Awards were announced on Wednesday. The FX drama “Shogun” had 25 nominations, the most of any series this year. The FX comedy “The Bear,” which streams on Hulu, broke the record for most nominations for a comedy series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: Want to Go Viral? Tell Your Story in 22 Parts.
description: A Dickensian tradition finds a new audience on TikTok.
content: Time is money. That age-old aphorism is particularly true on TikTok, where holding onto viewers for even a single second longer can translate into greater algorithmic reach and, thus, higher earning potential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: What to Know About the Trump Shooting Investigations
description: Multiple inquiries by law enforcement, Congress and federal agencies aim to understand how a would-be assassin was able to fire at Donald J. Trump.
content: As the F.B.I. investigates the attempt to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump at a campaign rally, Congress and the Homeland Security Department have begun their own inquiries into broader security failures, including by the Secret Service, that allowed the attack to take place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Way That Democrats Aren’t Standing Up to Biden Is Awfully Familiar
description: Democrats are putting loyalty to a leader over country. Sound familiar?
content: Before I get to President Biden, let me tell you about my love for a different presidential candidate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: To Revitalize Britain’s Economy, a Plan for a Stronger Government Role
description: The Labour Party’s economic agenda, like many other programs around the world, puts political leaders more firmly in charge of industrial policy.
content: The last time a freshly minted Labour government unabashedly campaigned on an ambitious national industrial policy to revive the British economy was 50 years ago, and the results were generally viewed as disastrous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: Amtrak Passengers Face Record Delays From Extreme Weather
description: The dated U.S. rail infrastructure is struggling to stay operational as climate change accelerates and intense heat waves, downpours and high winds become more frequent.
content: On June 20, after millions of Americans had suffered through a sweltering heat wave for three days, Amtrak sent an ominous warning over social media: Trains connecting the largest cities in Northeast could face up to an hour of delay from high temperatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Why Donald Glover Is Saying Goodbye to Childish Gambino
description: “Bando Stone & the New World,” his new album due Friday, tells a story about the potential end of the world — and the conclusion of his pseudonymous musical project.
content: Donald Glover had been walking a New York City street only a moment when a young man, perhaps in his early 20s, called out to him from several yards away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Halloween in July? Welcome to ‘Summerween.’
description: Spookiness meets the heat in a holiday now gaining traction online.
content: On a hot summer day, Bonnie Barton hosted a festive backyard gathering that looked different from the typical summertime pool party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Simon
title: J.D. Vance Keeps Selling His Soul. He’s Got Plenty of Buyers.
description: Exactly what the vice-presidential candidate has renounced in exchange for power is in the public record for all to see.
content: At the outset of Christopher Marlowe’s late 16th-century play “The Tragical History of Dr. Faustus,” the scholar at the center of the tale abandons all the learning he has mastered. Law, philosophy, medicine — none of these have fulfilled his boundless ambition. Instead, he turns to magic, making the fateful decision to sell his soul to the demon Mephistopheles, for what he “most desires” — “a world of profit and delight, /Of power, of honor.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Trump Tells Taiwan to Expect a Higher Price Tag for U.S. Defense
description: Trump also accused Taiwan of sinking the U.S. semiconductor sector, signaling he wants a more transactional approach to shielding the island from China.
content: Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, said that Taiwan should pay the United States for defending it from China, a remark highlighting the uncertainties — and high stakes — of how he might handle the smoldering Taiwan Strait dispute if he should win a second term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Judge Orders Boss Who Coughed at Employee During Pandemic to Pay Damages
description: The ruling by a tribunal judge in Britain highlighted the challenges and missteps businesses encountered during the early days of the pandemic.
content: A judge in Wales has ordered a businessman to pay a former employee thousands of pounds in damages for deliberately coughing at her during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Nevada Conservative Accused of Fraud Over Fund-Raising for Charity
description: Michele Fiore, a colorful figure in the state’s politics, took donations intended for a slain officer’s statue and used them for personal expenses, prosecutors said.
content: Michele Fiore, a Nevada politician known for her fiery brand of conservatism, was indicted on fraud charges on Tuesday for what prosecutors said was a scheme to spend charitable donations on personal expenses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: This Stegosaurus (Skeleton) Is for Sale
description: Apex, a dinosaur who roamed the Earth 150 million years ago, is to be auctioned off at Sotheby’s.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll meet a stegosaurus that is about to get a new owner. We’ll also get details on Senator Robert Menendez’s conviction on corruption charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Long Holes Look Intimidating, but It’s the Short Ones That Often Befuddle Golfers
description: At the British Open at Royal Troon, a short hole called the Postage Stamp has ended many title runs.
content: The British Open at Royal Troon in Scotland this week might help answer a question vexing professional golf. Is the antidote to golfers hitting increasingly long drives creating holes that are even longer? Or is it the opposite: incredible shortness?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Nikki Haley Endorses Trump and Urges Republicans to Unite Behind Him
description: In a speech at her party’s nominating convention, Ms. Haley gave her full support to the former president after a bruising primary campaign.
content: Nikki Haley, who held out the longest among the rivals of former President Donald J. Trump in the Republican primaries, formally endorsed him on Tuesday at the party’s nominating convention, urging her supporters to set aside their disagreements and stand united with their party for the good of the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Agrawal
title: How to Spot the Signs of Heat Exhaustion
description: There are simple ways to address it quickly. Here’s what to know.
content: Dangerously high temperatures across much of the United States have increased the risk of heat exhaustion and other heat-related illnesses. Knowing the signs of heat exhaustion and how to treat it can help prevent more serious problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Four Tornadoes Touch Down in Upstate New York, Killing 1
description: The tornadoes swept through Central New York during a week of extreme weather in the region. The worst of the damage was in the city of Rome, east of Syracuse.
content: The steeple on the oldest church in Rome, N.Y., built in 1853, crumpled. A mural of an American revolutionary was destroyed when the red brick building it decorated collapsed in the wind. The windows of businesses were shattered and shards of glass were strewed across downtown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Improvised Bombs Found in Gunman’s Car at Trump Rally Used a Radio-Control System
description: A report obtained by The Times detailed the bombs’ rudimentary construction, made with the kind of initiators used for fireworks shows.
content: Following the killing of the gunman who tried to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday during a rally in Butler, Pa., investigators discovered two improvised explosive devices in the would-be assassin’s car that used a radio-controlled initiation system designed for commercial fireworks demonstrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Robert Pearson, Hair Stylist Turned Acclaimed Barbecue Chef, Dies at 87
description: His Texas-style brisket, made with exacting precision, inspired a generation of New York City pit masters, who opened a wave of smoky joints in the 2000s.
content: Robert Pearson, who never lost his cockney accent through a career that began with combat service in the Royal Air Force followed by nearly two decades as an acclaimed hair stylist in London and New York, and that then took an improbable turn into Texas-style barbecue, where he earned renown as the best pit master north of the Mason-Dixon Line, died on July 8 at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Judy Chicago on Coming to Grips With Mortality
description: At 84, the feminist artist, writer and lecturer has learned that it’s not good to have an adversarial relationship with aging or death.
content: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, Judy Chicago explains, in her own words, what continues to motivate her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Thielman
title: Pulp Homage and Art-School Laughs Brighten July’s Graphic Novels
description: An unlovable heroine, a cyborg in search of missing parts, the restoration of a classic work and a series that is always worth the wait highlight four new volumes.
content: A rule I’ve developed is that if a book makes me laugh loudly enough to be embarrassing on the train, I have to find a way to write about it. In that spirit, THE WENDY AWARD, by Walter Scott (Drawn & Quarterly, 200 pp. $22.95) is the latest and arguably greatest in Scott’s screamingly funny series about Wendy, a fine artist whose work about a fictional character named Wanda draws on her own life to a disturbing degree. (Just so you’ve got that straight: Walter, who is a real fine artist, makes comics about Wendy, the heroine of the book, who makes comics about Wanda.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ismail Muhammad
title: Sports Celebrations Have Become Nostalgia Cosplay
description: Players love recreating memorable images from basketball’s past.
content: After the Boston Celtics won the N.B.A. Finals last month — defeating the miserable-looking Dallas Mavericks in a gentleman’s sweep, four games to one — the star forward Jayson Tatum made his way to the sidelines for a postgame interview with the veteran reporter Lisa Salters. Wearing a backward N.B.A. Champion cap on his head and wiping his face with a towel, he listened as Salters asked: “What does it feel like to finally be a champion?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: What if We Learn Nothing About the Man Who Shot Donald Trump?
description: America is a country where spectacular violence doesn’t require an explanation.
content: Eleven of the last 12 American presidents have endured an assassination attempt or a plot against their lives. The same is true for 20 of the country’s 45.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Tadej Pogacar Closes In on a Tour de France Win
description: Stage after stage he has taken time from his rival Jonas Vingegaard. Two tough Alpine stages remain before the race ends on Sunday.
content: They are the two best riders in the Tour de France. That has been true for several years and has been clear these last few weeks racing up and down the mountains of France. But it seems like Tadej Pogacar is just better than Jonas Vingegaard this year, and now he is closing in on his third Tour victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Navy Exonerates Black Sailors Unfairly Convicted After World War II Disaster
description: The men had objected to working until safety concerns were addressed following an explosion at a port near San Francisco that claimed hundreds of lives.
content: On July 17, 1944, hundreds of sailors were loading ammunition onto two cargo ships in Port Chicago, Calif., not far from San Francisco, when an explosion powerful enough to be felt 50 miles away killed 320 of the men, most of them Black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Long Covid and Vaccination: What You Need to Know
description: A new study adds to evidence that the shots can reduce the chances of developing one of the most dreaded consequences of Covid.
content: A summer wave of Covid is surging in many parts of the nation. Infections, emergency room visits and hospitalizations are all on the upswing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: New York City Bill Would Mandate Air-Conditioning for Tenants
description: Landlords have to keep tenants warm in the winter, but can leave them sweating in the summer. A city councilman wants to change that.
content: As New York City endures its third heat wave of the year, a city councilman plans to introduce a bill this week that would require landlords to buy, install and maintain air-conditioning units or cooling systems for tenants during the summer, with fines of up to $1,250 per day for noncompliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: ‘Black Pill’ and the Dark Anarchy of Our Political Moment
description: A new book by the journalist Elle Reeve describes how the extremist internet bled into the mainstream.
content: I found out during a live comedy show that the former president had been shot at. My phone was locked in a pouch and when the first comic told the audience that Donald Trump appeared to have survived an assassination attempt, we couldn’t tell if it was a bit. The second comic confirmed what the first one said, and joked that if this had happened in another era, they probably would have canceled the show. But at this point we’re all so primed for political chaos and inured to news of fresh violence that the audience — including me — barely reacted. In our defense, none of it seemed real.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse, Michael S. Schmidt, Reid J. Epstein, Peter Baker and Luke Broadwater
title: Biden Called ‘More Receptive’ to Hearing Pleas to Step Aside
description: The president has given no indication that he is changing his mind about staying in the race but is said to be more willing to listen to the case for bowing out.
content: President Biden has become more receptive in the last several days to hearing arguments about why he should drop his re-election bid, Democrats briefed on his conversations said on Wednesday, after his party’s two top leaders in Congress privately told him they were deeply concerned about his prospects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Vance Will Introduce Himself to American Voters
description: Also, new details emerged about the attempted assassination of Donald Trump. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: J.D. Vance is 39 years old and has spent just 18 months as the junior senator from Ohio; he had never even attended a national political convention before this year. But tonight, the newly minted Republican vice-presidential nominee will introduce himself to millions of Americans as one of the party’s most powerful figures.
source.name: The New York Times
